description: A Queensland judge has warned that a violent attack which left a policeman fighting for his life has the potential to encourage US-style police brutality.
text:
"You mowed the officer down. It was both cowardly and callous," Judge Leanne
Clare told the Brisbane District Court on Friday while sentencing Townshend to
a decade behind bars."The car was your weapon.""You deliberately forced the
vehicle onto flesh and bone."Judge Clare said it was a serious and violent
assault on an officer who was acting within the law to protect the
community."It was kind of offence that has the potential to deter good men and
women from the service," she said."It also has the potential to encourage
either inaction or heavy-handedness and the abuse of power with terrible
consequences."Recent overseas events are a tragic reminder of the importance
of well-trained officers who act with restraint and integrity."Senior
Constable Izzard had been attempting to hail down Townshend in the north
Brisbane suburb of Chermside in September 2018 when he was struck.Instead of
stopping, Townshend accelerated and ploughed into the officer.The impact threw
Senior Constable Izzard onto the bonnet, shattering the windscreen. He was
then flung onto the roof of the car as Townshend sped from the scene.The car
travelled 30 metres before Townshend deliberately swerved, throwing Senior
Constable Izzard onto the road.A dash-cam video from a police vehicle showed
him lying motionless after the incident."The impact broke Officer Izzard's
protective gear and his gun. It also shattered his body," Judge Clare
said."You left Senior Constable Izzard broken and bleeding on the
footpath."Doctors fought to save his life but they were not hopeful.They told
the father-of-two's family and colleagues to prepare for his death."I will
never forget the sight of all the blood and the intermittent yelling and
horrified screaming coming from Aaron as we treated him," a fellow police
officer, who asked not to be named, told the court in a victim impact
statement.Townshend fled the scene and was later found hiding in his father's
backyard shed."You gave a fanciful story," Judge Clare said."Any remorse
expressed was belated and not very convincing."He later pleaded guilty to a
malicious act with intent.Townshend was also convicted of unlawfully using a
motor vehicle and driving under the influence of methylamphetamine.Senior
Constable Izzard made a "miracle" recovery following brain surgery but he
continues to suffer from numerous life-changing injuries, including relearning
how to walk and talk.The officer sobbed as Judge Clare told the court he was
also no longer able to remember the birth of his children.Townshend will have
to serve at least 80 per cent of his sentence before being eligible for
parole.AAPMost Viewed in Loading

title: Queensland man who ran down policeman jailed [Sydney Morning Herald, The (Australia)]
html: "You mowed the officer down. It was both cowardly and callous," Judge Leanne Clare told the Brisbane District Court on Friday while sentencing Townshend to a decade behind bars."The car was your weapon.""You deliberately forced the vehicle onto flesh and bone."Judge Clare said it was a serious and violent assault on an officer who was acting within the law to protect the community."It was kind of offence that has the potential to deter good men and women from the service," she said."It also has the potential to encourage either inaction or heavy-handedness and the abuse of power with terrible consequences."Recent overseas events are a tragic reminder of the importance of well-trained officers who act with restraint and integrity."Senior Constable Izzard had been attempting to hail down Townshend in the north Brisbane suburb of Chermside in September 2018 when he was struck.Instead of stopping, Townshend accelerated and ploughed into the officer.The impact threw Senior Constable Izzard onto the bonnet, shattering the windscreen. He was then flung onto the roof of the car as Townshend sped from the scene.The car travelled 30 metres before Townshend deliberately swerved, throwing Senior Constable Izzard onto the road.A dash-cam video from a police vehicle showed him lying motionless after the incident."The impact broke Officer Izzard's protective gear and his gun. It also shattered his body," Judge Clare said."You left Senior Constable Izzard broken and bleeding on the footpath."Doctors fought to save his life but they were not hopeful.They told the father-of-two's family and colleagues to prepare for his death."I will never forget the sight of all the blood and the intermittent yelling and horrified screaming coming from Aaron as we treated him," a fellow police officer, who asked not to be named, told the court in a victim impact statement.Townshend fled the scene and was later found hiding in his father's backyard shed."You gave a fanciful story," Judge Clare said."Any remorse expressed was belated and not very convincing."He later pleaded guilty to a malicious act with intent.Townshend was also convicted of unlawfully using a motor vehicle and driving under the influence of methylamphetamine.Senior Constable Izzard made a "miracle" recovery following brain surgery but he continues to suffer from numerous life-changing injuries, including relearning how to walk and talk.The officer sobbed as Judge Clare told the court he was also no longer able to remember the birth of his children.Townshend will have to serve at least 80 per cent of his sentence before being eligible for parole.AAPMost Viewed in Loading
